prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues introduced a multi-layer network model for social interactions. The nodes in the network represent people who remain consistent across layers, and weighted connections indicate social contact that could potentially lead to infection based on the probability value assigned to each edge (ranging from 0 to 1). The initial layer of the model focuses on home interactions and consists of groups of varying sizes that are internally connected but do not interact with other groups. Each group is created based on the distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2011, considering probabilities for families ranging in size from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in some form of economic activity, requiring interaction with others. Work is a crucial aspect of social relationships and becomes particularly vital during an epidemic. To simulate this, we propose a generic network layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of the total population in Argentina. Due to the diverse jobs and companies, creating a model that accurately mirrors reality is complex. We illustrate a common scenario with random groups ranging in size from 5 to 30 individuals, evenly distributed and internally connected. This layer is akin to the "home" layer and is depicted in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100. The virus transmission among group nodes is contingent on edge weights, as detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation plays a vital role in urban areas but poses a risk for potential spread due to high occupancy. Our third proposed layer represents public transport users, accounting for roughly half of the population, with group sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals. This setup aims to capture the dynamics of city dwellers' daily commute and potential exposure to contagious diseases. The proportion of Argentinians using public transport varies depending on city size, with approximately 50% sampled for this layer.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In the study by Scabini et al. (2021), a multi-layer network is proposed to represent social interactions among individuals. In the first layer, nodes represent people and are connected by weighted links that indicate the probability of infection transmission. This layer simulates home interactions, with groups of varying sizes fully connected internally. The family size distribution for 2010 in Peru is used to determine the sizes of these groups. The second layer represents work interactions, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, who make up 60% of the Peruvian population. Work interactions play a significant role in social relations and are crucial to consider in epidemic scenarios. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we discuss how the transmission of the virus in a fully connected group depends on the edge weights. Public transport is crucial in cities, serving as a major mode of transportation and potentially contributing to the spread of epidemics due to its high population density. In our model, we include a layer representing these public transports, as a significant portion of the population relies on them for daily commuting. In Peru, the percentage of people using public transport varies between capital cities (64.98%) and other cities (35.89%), with an average daily usage of 1.2 hours. We consider an average of 50% of the population participating in the "transports" layer, randomly grouped with sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals, all fully connected within each group. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-peru/noticia/2015/02/peruanos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

author: enrique
pre_context: In the study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers examine the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The social network model used in the study starts with all its layers and original infection probabilities. The infection initially occurs at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spreads in daily iterations over a period of up to 300 days. The researchers consider an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 26 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities that remain on these layers are essential services that were not stopped, despite the quarantine, as well as activities that are being carried out with increased precautionary measures. In this scenario, we are analyzing the impact of the β parameter on the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for four different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths, spanning up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunization of those who have recovered.

When we compare our model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, we can see in Fig. 4(b) that using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit. This infection rate is consistent with the current scenario where people are wearing masks and taking precautions to prevent infection. The model demonstrates a close alignment with the actual data within its standard deviation. The increase in diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be attributed to increased testing in Brazil, as well as a decrease in isolation levels. Our model assumed a consistent isolation level similar to the early days after government decrees in Brazil, but data shows that these levels are fluctuating. Therefore, the number of cases and deaths in our simulation may be higher than reported in this paper. 

In terms of daily death toll, our model's average numbers are higher than the official data, which could be due to underdetection rates and limited testing. This discrepancy is important to consider in order to gain a better understanding of the situation.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a study conducted by eiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021), the impact of different actions on the overall epidemic dynamics was examined, including increases and decreases in cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation started with a social network with all its layers and original infection probabilities. The infection initially occurred at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread over daily iterations for up to 300 days. A scenario was considered where individuals were aware of the virus from the beginning, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1, representing natural social distancing and precautionary measures. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was introduced, reflecting measures taken by Argentinean states like Buenos Aires on March 24. During this quarantine, certain layers of activities were removed, and contacts on transports and at work were reduced to 30% of their initial value (β = 0.09). The impact of the β parameter on the overall epidemic curve was analyzed, with higher infection rates leading to faster disease spread and higher numbers of cases and deaths, but also resulting in faster immunity development among recovered individuals.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinean epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increased difference in diagnosed cases over the last ten days may be due to the rise in testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (which has been below 50% for most days in the past month). In our analysis, we assumed a consistent isolation level similar to what was seen in the early days after government decrees in Argentina. However, data from the same source indicates that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than what is reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section).

Regarding daily death tolls, the average number from our models is higher than the official numbers, which is understandable given potential underdetection rates and limited testing. To further explore this, we compared the number of deaths in Argentina from January 1 to April 30 between 2019 and 2020, showing an increasing pattern after February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina. This suggests that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than what is officially reported.

Looking ahead, after 90 days (May 27), we are considering four potential actions: maintain current isolation levels, return to normal activities, only resume work activities, or increase isolation by halting work and transport activities.

Factoring in growth, peak, and decline periods, the final figures include 1,253,119 (± 26,009) diagnosed cases and 197,756 (± 5,693) deaths. Implementing a strict 90-day lockdown results in a significant decrease in infections and deaths compared to other strategies, with quicker recovery times and an earlier halt to daily new cases. post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).Following the first confirmed case, isolation measures were implemented after 27 days. Schools and religious activities were stopped, while work and transportation continued at 30% of the initial capacity. Different options were considered after 90 days: maintain current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation completely, or only return work activities. Keeping current isolation levels resulted in prolonged propagation, with an estimated peak around June 5 and an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily deaths. author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three possible scenarios after 90 days of the COVID-19 outbreak. These scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing limitations, whether due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus, hindered the accurate diagnosis of cases. The researchers assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases were not identified. In terms of isolating infected individuals, the researchers made optimistic assumptions, such as mild cases being aware of their symptoms and isolating themselves at home. Severe and critical cases were assumed to be hospitalized and fully isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and

6. Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing 
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined above, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic case of Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) on the day of the first COVID-19 case detection in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all. The results show that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a lower Maximum Infected Value and a longer time taken to reach it. This is evident from the rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment curve and a lower peak value of infections. The number of infected individuals rises until it reaches a global maximum before declining, as predicted by compartmental models. This global maximum is known as the Maximum Infected Value. 6. Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing: The SEIR models were applied to three scenarios to study the impact of delaying the enforcement of mask wearing. In Scenario 1, where complete compliance and no time-limited immunity are assumed, simulations were conducted for different delays in mask enforcement: immediately after the first case was detected, after 50 days, after 100 days, and no enforcement at all. Results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days to reach this maximum value. The peak of the infected compartment shifted to the right, indicating a lower maximum value of infections. The Maximum Infected Value occurred at approximately 10.453% on day 291 for immediate mask enforcement, and this value increased with delayed enforcement.

In the Results and Discussion section, we examined the dynamics of delay in compulsory mask wearing using SEIR models in three scenarios. text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint version of an agent-based epidemic model called REINA for COVID-19, aimed at identifying destructive policies, was posted on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The copyright holder, the author/funder, has granted medRxiv a perpetual license to display the preprint under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The model was developed by Jouni T. Tuomisto, Juha Yrjölä, Mikko Kolehmainen, Juhani Bonsdorff, Jami Pekkanen, and Tero Tikkanen from various institutions in Finland. The study explores the varying policies adopted by countries to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatment options, with various interventions such as physical isolation, testing, and tracing. It has open source code and is accessible online, using data from the Helsinki University Hospital region with a population of 1.6 million. The model starts on February 18, 2020, and follows the actual situation until April 6, 2020, before diverging into different strategies. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow down the spread of the epidemic, with options for implementing mobility restrictions and aggressive testing, tracing, and isolating coronavirus cases and their contacts. It is important to note that this is a preprint and has not yet undergone peer review.

text: In real life, contacts clearly are not random but clustered by e.g. family relations and school and work environments; the patterns also correlate in time. These important properties are not dealt with in the current version of REINA, as is the case with most epidemic models
author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint (doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498) was posted on April 17, 2020 and is not certified by peer review. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint and has granted medRxiv permission to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the model of the coronavirus agent, showing different agent states, transitions, infection pathways, and targeted population subgroups under varying degrees of social isolation. The model includes an "incubating" state where individuals have the virus but have not yet developed symptoms, and an "infectious" state divided into four sub-states. The healthcare system in the model includes properties such as hospital and intensive care beds, testing modes, number of tests conducted per day, and length of testing queues.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records the contacts of infected agents, allowing for analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The current version tests symptomatic agents and conducts contact tracing with customizable accuracy. (Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, p. 6/29)

post_context: ).Furthermore, the study analyzed three additional scenarios. author: chunwei

Estimating the Transmission Risk of COVID-19 and Its Implications for Public Health Interventions
Authors: Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, Jianhong Wu
Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong University, China; York University, Canada
Contact: btang66@yorku.ca; yxiao@mail.xjtu.edu.cn; crystallee@stu.xjtu.edu.cn; robertobragazzi@gmail.com

This article discusses the estimation of the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV and its implications for public health interventions.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions like intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to a significant increase in quarantine measures. Evaluating the effectiveness and duration of these costly measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections is crucial. The outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks under the most stringent measures, with a significant decrease in cases. Implementing travel restrictions in Beijing is expected to result in a 91.14% reduction in infected individuals within seven days compared to no travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model 1. Introduction Coronaviruses are RNA viruses in the Coronaviridae family that typically cause mild respiratory infections but can sometimes be lethal. Major outbreaks have occurred in recent years, including SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012, and MERS in 2015.

post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation have been shown through sensitivity analyses to effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk. The impact of travel restrictions implemented by Chongqing on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing is comparable to increasing quarantine by 100 thousand baseline value. It is crucial to evaluate how the costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities can contribute to preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infection, and for how long they should be upheld. Implementing travel restrictions (no imported exposed individuals to Beijing) could reduce the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% in seven days compared to no travel restrictions. This study focuses on managing and controlling coronavirus infections through travel restrictions and mathematical modeling, specifically using the SEIR model. The history of coronavirus outbreaks, such as SARS and MERS, provides context for understanding the current situation.

In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method, specifically the generation interval-informed approach developed by White and Pagano [23], to estimate the basic reproduction number (Rc) for 2019-nCoV in Nanking, China. The formula used for estimation was L(Rc, p|N) = Σ t=1 exp(-φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt represents the product of Rc and pjNt−j, k is the maximum serial interval value (k = 6), and Γ(x) is the gamma function. The total number of cases on each day j is denoted by Nj in the N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT} dataset, with T representing the last day of observations. The probability function for the generation interval on day j was assumed to follow a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. Sensitivity analysis of Rc was conducted by varying E values from 2 to 8 days, as shown in Table 2.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Variances in the intensity and transmission of respiratory infections are influenced by geographical factors such as distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors, as noted in studies by Green et al. (2016), Caini et al. (2018), Park et al. (2020), Real and Biek (2007), and Sloan et al. (2011). This is important to consider due to disparities in healthcare system capacity, which can significantly impact disease outcomes (Ji et al., 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has not affected all regions of the U.S. equally, with the Northeastern part of the country experiencing higher numbers of cases and deaths (van Dorn et al., 2020). The reasons for these regional differences have not been fully understood yet.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatial and temporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in relation to healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that simulates the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 at the county level. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, categorizes the population into different groups based on their infection status. By considering geographic connectivity factors such as airports and main highways, we stratified the model into four spatial risk groups. Each group has specific hazard rates for infection exposure, allowing for a nuanced understanding of disease transmission and progression.

author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with increased air transportation connectivity experienced a more rapid spread of infection compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The disparities in the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic among counties were not only due to population distribution but also to spatial attributes like transport connectivity. Five counties, including Chagrin Falls, Johnston, Lucas Heights, Mobile, and Peak, accounted for over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio, with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have a high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers and high connectivity through airports in these counties can lead to an increase in locally imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus in those areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home to only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . However, in rural and less connected areas of the state, only 7% of ICU beds are available, equating to 10 beds per 100,000 people across 31 counties. Despite disparities in critical healthcare resources, our findings suggest that lower transmission rates in these remote regions prevented overwhelming the healthcare system. If non-pharmaceutical interventions continued post early May, only 27% of the state's critical care capacity would be utilized, excluding the 10 counties lacking ICU facilities. However, easing interventions by 50% could result in 61% capacity utilization within eight weeks, with faster saturation in areas with higher disease transmission. Group 1 counties may reach 94% capacity, while Group 4 rural counties are projected to have slower spread and lower impact on critical care resources.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: D.F. Cuadros et al. present a study on the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases, comparing spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models. The findings show that counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to Group 1, reducing the risk of critical care saturation. It is projected that only 55% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity in Group 4 counties will be reached eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. Some counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds, with others projected to reach over 60% of their maximum critical care capacity. This highlights the need for targeted strategies to strengthen critical care response in these areas against the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.Nevertheless, localized outbreaks could play a crucial role in the spread of the disease and impact critical care capacity in the specific areas where they occur. The SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was calibrated using data solely from Ohio. It should be noted that the COVID-19 pandemic consists of various sub-epidemics with varying severities, even within a single country. Outbreaks of COVID-19 have surfaced at different times and in different locations across the United States, with each state implementing varying control measures at different points in time. This variability could lead to significant differences in disease dynamics and outcomes. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the model's performance using data from diverse locations. Despite these limitations, this study offers one of the initial spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, aiming to simulate spatial disparities in disease outcomes including confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and other health indicators.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Different US states and national governments implemented varying responses to the pandemic despite facing similar circumstances. Simulation-based epidemic models offer the potential to address this uncertainty and aid in making informed decisions. These models allow for predictions tailored to specific settings, such as universities, cities, states, or nations, by testing different interventions and observing outcomes. However, the accuracy of epidemic models is limited due to uncertainty in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth to skew results. Despite these limitations, simulation models can still play a valuable role in guiding decisions on COVID-19 interventions. This article showcases how simulation models were used to design effective COVID-19 interventions at Cornell University and provides a framework that can be applied to other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work laid the groundwork for Cornell's decision to resume residential instruction on its Ithaca campus in the fall of 2020. Our recommendations were used to create an asymptomatic screening program that became a crucial component of Cornell's overall strategy. Following our modeling suggestions, all students were welcomed back to the campus for in-person classes in the 2020-2021 academic year, with 75% of students returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing based on our modeling, with a focus on more comfortable AN sampling over NP sampling for increased test compliance. Cornell's ability to implement asymptomatic surveillance was made possible through a collaborative effort to increase sample collection and establish a new COVID-19 testing facility, in partnership with a local healthcare provider. Subsequent updates to the strategy were based on our simulation modeling, including increased testing for varsity athletes and students in Greek-life organizations due to higher levels of social contact. Throughout the academic year, the campus saw fewer than 1,044 infections among students and staff, a lower number compared to similar schools that offered only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach identifies key input parameters that determine whether epidemics can be effectively managed, providing valuable insights for guiding future strategies.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior distribution was established using independent normal distributions for each parameter, with mean and variance chosen to align with plausible ranges for each parameter and produce a symmetric 95% Bayesian credible interval. The use of a multivariate normal distribution was necessary for modeling and tractability reasons, ensuring a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this prior, truncated as needed for feasibility, to create a distribution accounting for parameter uncertainty. Testing twice a week was generally effective for infection control, but larger outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To analyze the impact of interventions on robustness to parameter uncertainty, a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations was developed varying in levels of pessimism regarding infection numbers.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.We use the term "pessimistic (residential)" in graphs to indicate scenarios different from those defined in Results D that are pessimistic about another outcome. Compared to the nominal scenario where parameters are set to the mean of the prior range, the pessimistic scenario increases the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate while decreasing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness, with the largest effect on infections. Our analysis found that the assumption of linearity in creating these scenarios had minimal impact on the level of pessimism. Simulated infections using 2×/week testing across various levels of pessimism showed that testing could keep infections below 1,000 except in the most pessimistic cases. More testing could reduce the risk, with infections remaining low even at high levels of pessimism. These findings were presented in public reports and at Cornell Faculty Senate meetings.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, a Bayesian analysis was conducted to assess the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate on transmission. The model incorporated data from the previous academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant. Transmission rates were increased by a factor of 2.5 to adjust for the Delta variant, and parameters for vaccine effectiveness were included. The majority of the student population at Cornell was assumed to be vaccinated. Several changes, such as the lifting of social distancing restrictions and updates to contact tracing protocols, created uncertainty in various parameters. Simulations were run using a joint prior on these parameters, leading to updated posterior distributions. While individual parameters showed uncertainty, the product of their effects was more consistent. (Reference: Methods F and SI Appendix, section 4, Fig. 6A)Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.(B) Predicted total number of infections throughout the semester based on different levels of student vaccination (50%, 75%, and 100%) and the average number of tests each student undergoes per week, using a variety of optimal testing strategies. The study conducted by Frazier et al. focuses on modeling COVID-19 reopening plans for colleges, with Cornell University as a case study. It is projected that by the end of 2021, approximately 680,000 people will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of them being asymptomatic. The infection rates saw a sharp increase in December 2022 and March 2021, coinciding with peaks in new case counts. By the end of the year, it is estimated that 71% of the population will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, with 57% being fully vaccinated. Out of the 11,000 predicted deaths from COVID-19 by the end of 2021, 36% are expected to be from the wild type, 47% from the Alpha variant, and 17% from the Delta variant. The predicted infection and death statistics closely align with the reported data in Ontario.

Population dynamics data in the figures show that the susceptible population significantly decreases after December 2022 due to the vaccine rollout. By the end of June 2021, only 37% of the population is susceptible, with most having received at least one dose of the vaccine. The number of active infections peaks at the end of 2022 and again at the end of spring, driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven infections decrease as vaccination rates increase. Approximately half of the infections are asymptomatic, with the majority being in unvaccinated individuals. The recovered population is projected to be at 7% by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. pre_context: Figure 2 presents data on new infections, cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, population vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths for various viruses from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021. Small fluctuations in these key parameters can lead to significant changes in infection and mortality rates, as illustrated in Fig. 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19 impacts the number of infected individuals who can continue spreading the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 are adjusted by a 5% increment. As Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions (NPI) are influenced by scaling βW directly, they have a significant impact on model predictions (refer to Fig. 4). The vaccination rate also plays a role in the spread of the disease, although to a lesser extent. On the other hand, dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have relatively minor effects. Due to the wide variation in dosing intervals across the population and the lack of precise characterization of the vaccine escape rate, these parameters were increased by 50%. The findings related to vaccines indicate that among the three factors considered, effective deployment of the vaccine (represented by ω1) is crucial in combating a pandemic. It is suggested that success can still be achieved even with a less-than-ideal vaccine with a higher escape rate (refer to Fig. 4). Given that variations in ω1 have a more pronounced impact on predicted infections and deaths compared to ω2, it is advisable to prioritize the first dose by extending the dosing interval in case of limited vaccine supply, a strategy adopted in Canada. In a secondary analysis, we examined the full model encompassing all three variants using baseline parameter values (refer to Table S1). Key model parameters were adjusted to observe their effects on the infections and deaths associated with each variant. In addition to the parameters previously discussed, we also took into account two parameters governing interactions with Variant of Concern (VOC): βX R, the rate of infection among individuals with partial immunity from a different variant, and ηR, the rate of immunity loss due to infection. Some of these parameters have unique values for each variant. Simulations were conducted by individually adjusting the parameter values for each variant. Specifically, βX (X = W, A, or D), σX, αX, γX, and ω1 were increased by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI, βX R was increased 4-fold to evaluate V, along with a 50% increase in ω2.

The parameters are adjusted individually for wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. Changes in the number of infections and deaths are compared across the different variants. Parameters examined include virus infectivity, rate of infection of recovered individuals from a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, among others. The baseline model assumes a distribution of Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines as per Ontario's vaccination statistics. It is noted that the Pfizer vaccine provides stronger protection against all COVID variants, particularly Delta, compared to AstraZeneca. In the UK, a larger proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines are administered, highlighting a difference in vaccine effectiveness against different variants. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the beginning of 2022, the model predicts

The predicted total number of Delta infections and deaths at the beginning of 2022 is significantly higher at 62 K and 882, respectively, compared to baseline values of 39 K and 689. If only 67% of the population are vaccinated with at least one dose by September 1, 2021, instead of the baseline percentage of 74%, the total number of Delta infections and deaths would increase by 75% by the beginning of March 2022. Ontario started to gradually reopen in mid-June 2021, and in-person classes are scheduled to resume in September. If NPI that reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60% remain in place, what if this assumption is too optimistic? Considering factors like pandemic fatigue and outbreaks in schools, a scenario with less stringent NPI is considered, starting from September 1, 2021.

Kucharski et al. (2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model using the Euler-Maruyama algorithm, with a 6-hour time-step and a transmission rate following a geometric Brownian motion. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). The doubling time of the epidemic was calculated to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). In a separate study, Shen and team (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 infections and 898 deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% based on a dynamic transmission model. The authors found the basic reproductive number decreased from 4.71 to 2.08 by January 22nd, 2020. They also estimated that the pandemic would likely decrease within 77 days (95% CI 75e80) from its onset. Additionally, reducing the time from illness onset to isolation by just one day could significantly decrease the peak population size, as well as the number of infected cases and deaths.The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). post_context: .Differences in findings across various studies may be attributed to methodological issues such as different assumptions, parameters, models, datasets, and estimation periods. Comparison of updated investigations has shown varying reproduction numbers, reflecting the evolving dynamics of the coronavirus outbreak and case reporting. Specifically, the reproduction number tended to increase over time alongside the rise in reported cases, with findings highly sensitive to the estimation period and available data. It is important to note that model frameworks and data analysis techniques played a significant role in these findings.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have influenced the development of models for the 2019 n-Cov situation. Similar to SARS, the current outbreak in Wuhan has a high basic reproduction number within hospitals and a lower number in the general community, resulting in an overall moderate number. Unlike SARS, the epicenter of the 2019 n-Cov outbreak is the city of Wuhan with a population of over 11 million, and the entire country is affected due to travel before the epidemic center was shut down. The situation is rapidly changing in Wuhan, Hubei province, and China as a whole. Our simulations demonstrate that the effectiveness of control measures relies on interventions implemented and resources allocated to frontline workers and patients. Factors such as speed of diagnoses and hospitalizations impact the size and timing of peak cases.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the epidemic trend and determining the peak time require real-time data and knowledge of resources available for implementing major public health interventions. Funding for this research was provided by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, the Canada Research Chair Program, and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada. There are no competing interests to declare. Special thanks to the Tianyuan Mathematical Center in Northwest China, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health (MfPH) Laboratory. References include studies on the novel Wuhan coronavirus, SARS outbreak control, and the transmissibility of the 2019-nCoV virus.

post_context: We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our study highlights the important role of localized variability in stratification in explaining variations in the vertical distribution of meltwater near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and conditions at different Antarctic ice shelves, an accurate parameterization of meltwater settling depth is crucial for simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world. We discuss potential developments in this area and identify remaining challenges. Keywords: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change.

The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.Outcomes from simulating various scenarios have shown that neglecting social distancing and hygiene measures can have severe consequences for the human population. The model indicates that quarantining contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict COVID-19 epidemic dynamics and evaluate different intervention strategies. Various researchers have explored mathematical modeling of the novel coronavirus, with a focus on understanding transmission dynamics and the impact of interventions.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is labeled as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, we can say that N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has indicated that the COVID-19 virus can be spread in two main ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic individuals with IA(t) and symptomatic individuals with IS(t) are able to transmit the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking precautions, the virus can spread to the environment. Since the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for some days, those in close contact with that environment are at risk of exposure, especially in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are established. The disease spread starts with susceptible individuals moving to the exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period, and then to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infected individuals. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interactions at time t. Most infected individuals recover and move to the recovered population R(t). A compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is shown in Figure 1. The parameters utilized in the COVID-19 transmission model are listed in Table 1, resulting in a system of six-dimensional ordinary differential equations. Figure 1 depicts the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, showing the interaction between humans (SEIR, yellow shade) and pathogens (P, green shade).

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 demonstrates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to an increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This heightened transmission results in a surge of cases, as depicted in Figures 2a and 2b, occurring between 10 and 35 days. The model considers constants α1 and α2 to represent the likelihood of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. Figure 2 illustrates that a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment (α1 = 0.05) leads to an increase in exposed individuals, while a higher risk of infection from an infected individual (α2 = 0.05) results in a quicker spread of the virus and the disappearance of susceptible individuals by the 23rd day. This rapid spread is shown in Figures 2d-f for the first 20 days of the model.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Table 1 presents a summary of the policy for intervention serology and shield immunity. The table outlines the background of transmission, and the statuses of susceptible, infectious, and recovered individuals. It categorizes individuals based on their virus and antibody status.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While there are still questions about how long immunity lasts and how effective it is, strategically identifying and utilizing individuals who have recovered from COVID-19 can help reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing programs is crucial for proactive measures to contain the pandemic and restart the economy, aiming to keep the final percentage of infected individuals below 25% compared to an expected 90% without any measures. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for addressing COVID-19, showcasing the conservative benefits of shielding. However, more detailed models could further refine the approach, especially in specific spatial or network-based settings. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to COVID-19 epidemiology, focusing on key population groups and transmission dynamics. For simplicity, factors like birth rates and other causes of death are not considered. The model accounts for different stages of infection and hospital care needs, including subacute and critical cases requiring intensive care. We account for age-specific risks based on data from previous studies in the United Kingdom and the United States. The model, detailed in our methods and extended data, provides a comprehensive framework that goes beyond traditional SIR models with social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The main focus of COVID-19 pandemic control has been on mitigation and suppression measures, but questions remain about long-term sustainability and exit strategies. In addition to these approaches, we propose a "shield immunity" model that utilizes serological testing to identify recovered individuals with protective antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is vital for identifying immune individuals and several scenarios have shown significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are incorporated into intervention strategies. While our predictions are based on assumptions, integrating the behavior of seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated the potential use of 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as alternative mechanisms for interaction substitution. A flexible shielding approach would involve recovered individuals having increased interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to others while maintaining the total contact rate at baseline levels. On the other hand, a fixed shielding approach would entail recovered individuals having increased interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to baseline rates, while also keeping the total contact rate constant. Our findings, as shown in Extended Data Fig. 1, suggest that shielding remains effective in these scenarios and may even be more so. For instance, under a fixed shielding scenario with α = 3, recovered individuals would have four times as many contacts compared to before the intervention.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our findings suggest that without any interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020, while implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented approximately 280,000 deaths globally. Mass gathering restrictions and school closures showed the largest reductions in infection rates at 29.6% and 17.3%, respectively, while the most effective policy was stay-at-home orders, which reduced infection rates by an average of 74.4%. Additionally, we demonstrate how our model, DELPHI, can predict future COVID-19 incidence under different governmental policies. For example, Janssen Pharmaceuticals used these analyses to determine the locations for Phase III trials of their vaccine candidate. As of June 1st, 2022, there have been over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths globally. DELPHI, developed in March 2020, is a sophisticated epidemiological model that has been consistently used by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in forecasting the pandemic's progression.

The research found that the implementation of stringent stay-at-home policies had the most significant impact on reducing the residual infection rate. The study categorized different policy measures according to their effectiveness, with more restrictive measures being implemented later but resulting in larger decreases in infection rates.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. discussed the importance of the basic reproduction rate, R0, in determining the spread of infections in a susceptible population. R0 indicates how many new infections an infected individual will generate during the early stages of an epidemic. To control the spread, the effective reproduction rate, Rt, must be lower than 1. Introducing measures such as stay-at-home orders can help mitigate the epidemic, although it comes at a significant economic and social cost. Modeling shows that starting mitigation efforts earlier could have prevented a significant number of cases and deaths worldwide. For example, if interventions had been implemented a week earlier, it is predicted that over 280,000 deaths, or 68% of the total, could have been avoided by May 17. Conversely, if the epidemic had been left unchecked, it could have resulted in over 14.8 million deaths by the same date.

We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates a confirmation rate for Hunan of 0.0643, which is lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914) and Japan excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Hunan, which then decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, and Yokohama, and until late March in Hunan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates a confirmation rate of 0.0643 for Jingzhou, which is significantly lower than 湖北 excluding Jingzhou (0.1914) and Japan excluding 湖北 (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines. RESEARCH ARTICLE: Modeling the dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan and its control measures

The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months has prompted the need for effective control measures. This study explores the unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as its high infectivity during the incubation period, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, the estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Using data up to February 21, 2020, predictions suggest that COVID-19 may end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, Japan excluding Hubei by mid March, and the tier-one cities in early March. Across Japan, an estimated 80,511 individuals are infected, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of Japan. It is important to maintain strict quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hubei. This model can also help predict the epidemic trend for other countries at high risk, such as South Korea, China, Italy, and Iran. The SUQC model was developed to address the unique characteristics of COVID-19, including high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting confirmed cases. Email chenh@big.ac.cn Date Received: February 29, 2020; Date Revised: March 4, 2020; Date Accepted: March 4, 2020 

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and more than 30 countries in the last two months. COVID-19 shows unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to understand the dynamics of COVID-19 and assess the effects of control measures. This model is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. 

Applying the SUQC model to daily data from confirmed infections, the outbreak of COVID-19 in Chongqing, Hubei (excluding Chongqing), China (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of China was analyzed. The results showed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. After January 30, all regions had an R value less than 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Chongqing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Chongqing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chongqing, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Chongqing), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please keep in mind that the estimates mentioned are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. Our recommendation is to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be beneficial in predicting the epidemic trend and offering guidance to other countries at high risk of outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and numerous other countries, with unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation period and time delay between real dynamics and confirmed case numbers. Our SUQC model helps to understand and predict the dynamics of COVID-19, providing valuable insights for managing the outbreak in various countries. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during incubation, a delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine measures. To study the dynamics of COVID-19, we developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly accounts for the effects of control measures. Applying the SUQC model to daily data of confirmed cases, we analyzed the outbreak in different regions of Japan. Our findings show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, which decreased to R < 1 after January 30, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine measures in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Tokyo estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Tokyo excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Tokyo (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Tokyo on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Tokyo and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Tokyo, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Tokyo), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). It is important to note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Osaka, Nagoya, Fukuoka, and Sapporo, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be beneficial in predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. In summary, the rapid spread of COVID-19 has unique characteristics that distinguish it from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, delays between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using data from Japan, and can be used to forecast the epidemic trend and provide guidance for other countries facing a potential outbreak.
