pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is calculated as 1 – g2 δ. A set of ODE equations is established to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the control by artificial factors. In the model, infected individuals either go directly to being confirmed or indirectly through quarantine. By simplifying the model, the direct route is eliminated. Biologically meaningful parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w) can be defined. The reproductive number of the infection is denoted as R=α/g1. Parameter inference is conducted on the cumulative confirmed infections (C(t)), which is the only variable with daily observed data for model fitting and parameter inference. The initial value of susceptible individuals (S(0)) is assumed to be equal to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections (C(0)) is obtained from official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the outbreak of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei province during February 20 and February 26. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this time period, the number of confirmed infections may provide a less biased representation of the natural behavior of COVID-19. In the early stages before February 20, confirmed numbers were small and fluctuating, influenced by strict quarantine measures in later stages. The parameter α is challenging to accurately estimate, with values varying from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods or data sets. Fortunately, an accurate value of α is not crucial in the SUQC model, as the overall infection ability measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1 is sensitive to parameter optimization, balancing any bias in α with g1. Other parameters and initial values, such as g1, β, U(0), and Q(0), are determined by fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model. The expected daily time series of confirmed infections, denoted as ^C=f(g1, β, U0, Q0), is solved using the fourth-order Runge-Kutta method with predetermined values of g1, β, U(0), and Q(0). The loss function, err(α, g1, U0, Q0)=||C - ^C||^2, is then optimized using the interior-point method in MATLAB to infer parameter values. Sensitivity analysis shows that the inferred values are not highly dependent on the initial values provided. Weighted loss functions were also explored to better incorporate information across the entire epidemic timeline, as the cumulative case numbers may give undue weight to later observations.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and economy. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional (ci∂ic) and the Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais. The article discusses the use of agent-based simulation and epidemic models, specifically the SEIR model, to study the COVID-19 pandemic. The study was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Thus, this tool is valuable for aiding politicians and health authorities in planning their responses to the COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, with the country being severely impacted since then. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. Beyond the health crisis, the pandemic has affected various aspects of life, such as politics, education, the economy, social interactions, the environment, and climate change. The most effective method to combat the outbreak is implementing strict social distancing measures, as supported by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying levels of success due to the complex nature of societies, making it difficult to predict the outcome.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The inclusion of uncertainties in data is essential in modeling, as it allows for flexibility by considering the data at each time point as following a probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance determined by the probability distribution assumed. The lack of data is a significant concern for modellers, as it can greatly impact predictions. One key factor that contributes to variability in model predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have sought medical attention, been tested, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed. The infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or testing status. Confirmed cases are just a fraction of the total infected population, similar to the tip of an iceberg above the water representing data, while the submerged portion represents the hidden epidemic of infected individuals not captured by testing or surveillance. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why might this present a challenge for modelers? During model calibration, it is crucial to adjust the model parameters, such as the transmission rate b, by considering the total number of infected individuals I(t) and applying the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different estimates for the transmission rate b can be obtained by fitting the model to the data, ultimately determining the basic reproduction number R0 and other key epidemic indicators. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in the context of COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary significantly, leading to a range of model predictions. This variability creates a challenge known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, where different combinations of parameter values can result in equally good fits to the data but yield markedly different projections of the epidemic. Resolving issues of nonidentifiability is essential for ensuring the reliability of model predictions. Traditional methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to address this issue effectively, as they rely on simple optimization techniques that may not accurately identify the best model parameters among multiple potential solutions.

It's important to distinguish between the latent period (time from infection to infectiousness) and the incubation period (time from infection to symptom onset). While evidence suggests that COVID-19 individuals can be infectious before showing symptoms, the duration of the latent period remains unclear. Compared to the SIR model, the strength of the SEIR model lies in its biological realism, but it introduces two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. post_context: the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 22, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.The mayor of Nanchang announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, prompting us to estimate the total population N in Nanchang on January 22 to be approximately 6 million. We utilized uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models, as listed in Tables 1 and 2. Posterior distributions for all estimated parameters were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. Best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these posterior distributions, with results presented in Table 1 for the SIR model and Table 2 for the SEIR model. After comparing the calibration results for both models, we calculated their corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc to be 174 and 186 for the SIR and SEIR models respectively. The significant difference of 12 between these values indicates that utilizing the SEIR model would result in a notable loss of information compared to the SIR model, leading us to continue our investigation using the latter. Additionally, we observed a linkage between the transmission rate b and the diagnosis rate r in the SIR model calibration results, as depicted in Fig. 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, such as technical, surveillance, or administrative data, and published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens, such as SARS in 2003 and COVID-19. Alternatively, better inference methods and model fitting algorithms can be employed to narrow the large confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Baseline predictions for Nanjing, including prediction intervals generated from sampling the posterior distribution, were based on newly confirmed cases reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This period included the lockdown and travel restrictions in Nanjing, but precedes additional control measures implemented after March 7, 2020. The projections provide estimates for the potential epidemic in Nanjing if further control measures were not put in place. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanjing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after March 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimates, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after March 7, the number of peak cases would reach around 120,000, and the Nanjing epidemic would not be resolved until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is a computational biology model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, taking into account the variability in the duration of symptoms and viral shedding. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may either recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of about 2.2-2.7. The specific value of β = 0.016 used in Covasim was calibrated based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were chosen to align with both time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types to ensure consistency. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of beta, representing the effectiveness of these measures. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness are accounted for in the model. Viral load, which affects infectivity, is highest around symptom onset and then decreases over time. The model incorporates two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with specific parameters. Daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability for each agent. Fig 2 displays the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals under default parameter values.

pre_context: In the model Covasim developed by PLOS COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY, the duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies widely, increasing with the severity of the illness. Different recovery times are assigned to asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The probability of virus transmission between susceptible and infectious individuals on a given day is represented by the parameter β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7. pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β should be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. If the network structure includes households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 chosen for consistency with relevant studies. Different factors, such as age-based susceptibility and interventions like physical distancing, can also impact the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on factors like disease severity and viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter.
